posts.title: Where to Start with Anne Rice
posts.text: While best known for her Gothic tales of vampires, she had a varied oeuvre that alluded to a vast imagination.

posts.title: Horror Lite: Books That Thrill
posts.text: These horror-adjacent titles are thrillers and chillers that skirt the horror genre yet still maintain a Hitchcockian flair that will keep readers on the edge of their seat.

posts.title: Quelques des meilleurs livres en français
posts.text: Il y a plusieurs de merveilleux livres écrits dans la langue français. Nous avons sélectionnées quelques auteurs et livres qui sont exceptionnels à notre avis.

posts.title: Quelques livres parisiens par arrondissement
posts.text: Nous avons trouvé ces livres géniaux sur les environs de Paris. Nous espérons que, vous aussi, vous trouverez dans un état d’esprit parisien.

posts.title: Unexpected Women in Early Science Fiction
posts.text: Women, sometimes writing under pseudonyms, were an important and influential part of the early science fiction landscape.The list is not comprehensive, but it gives you an idea of the wealth of science fiction work by women there is to explore.

posts.title: Doin' the Pigeon: Books About These Fascinating Birds
posts.text: These birds have a long history of being tools of communication and have played important roles in many wars. Here are some titles, both nonfiction and fiction, that delve into that history along with a book to kick off the list that takes a contemporary look at our relationship with pigeons.

posts.title: A Random Walk After Edgar Allan Poe
posts.text: There’s a lithograph of Edgar Allan Poe walking across High Bridge in the mid-1800. If you wanted to follow in his proverbial footsteps, you could take a lonely, socially distanced walk over this very same bridge today.

posts.title: Use Audiobooks to Get Your Mind and Body Moving
posts.text: We have a wide selection of e-audiobooks that patrons can access wherever they are and in conjunction with their fitness pursuits, whatever they may be.

posts.title: Books are Heavy
posts.text: Consider the weight of a book. (A big book.) Then consider its emotional weight... both can be a lot to carry around.

posts.title: The Play's the Thing: Featured Plays Inside Fiction Novels
posts.text: When Shakespeare placed a play within a play in Hamlet, his titular character realized "The play's the thing." This short list of recommended fiction all have a featured play within the narrative from Vanity Fair to Station Eleven.

posts.title: Amusing Muses: Artists Who Inspired Literature
posts.text: I was inspired by the movie Xanadu in which Olivia Newton-John is a Greek muse incarnated as a girl named Kira who inspires others to achieve. I got to thinking about books that were inspired by great works of art or by the lives of artists and created this list.

posts.title: Books for Circus Fans
posts.text: For anyone still contemplating running away with the circus, here is a small selection of some new circus-themed reads for adults.

posts.title: Spooky Halloween Reads
posts.text: Decorate your bookshelves this Halloween with spooky novels.

posts.title: Where to Find U.S. Environmental Data
posts.text: Here are some links to online environmental resources.

posts.title: Queuing Up
posts.text: Waiting in line is a great equalizer, and it's usually inevitable. Most everyone, if asked, would say they hate waiting in line, but there can also be a few rare moments of camaraderie.

posts.title: Time After Time
posts.text: We predict that in the year 2016 we will read several books about time travel.

posts.title: What to Read While You're Waiting for 'The Girl on the Train' Movie
posts.text: The Girl on the Train movie is slated to be released October 7, 2016. As that is still a ways away, here are some novel releases to tide you over.

posts.title: Zine Machine
posts.text: Imagine, if you will, a time when photocopiers had supplanted the lowly mimeograph machine. This technology gave way to the birth of the zine.

posts.title: Empathy for Animals, On Land and Underseas
posts.text: This summer, why not explore some great nonfiction science reads about animals, both on land and underseas, and the ways in which they continually surprise humans.

posts.title: Book Club Inception Books
posts.text: What are some book club books about book clubs? Or books that mention what books the characters are reading?

posts.title: Running Away With the Circus
posts.text: Have you ever wondered why no one ever calmly joins the circus?

posts.title: Color Philosophy and Synesthesia in Literature
posts.text: Color perception changes with how different people view different wavelengths of light, and depending on where you live and when you live/lived, you may have a very different experience.

posts.title: Madame Bovary's Cultural Mark
posts.text: Gustave Flaubert's Madame Bovary was more than just an exciting novel, it set a standard for novels, and created a buzzword about having a glamorized, exaggerated conception about oneself.

posts.title: Physicists Who Looked To Literature
posts.text: Literature provides ample inspiration to scientific fields, as these examples show—and vice versa.

posts.title: Reader's Den: The Secret History of Wonder Woman, Part 4
posts.text: Critical reception and further reading from the author, Jill Lepore.

posts.title: Reader's Den: The Secret History of Wonder Woman, Part 3
posts.text: This week, let's take a look at the cultural impact and uses of Wonder Woman through these resources for further reading.

posts.title: Reader's Den: The Secret History of Wonder Woman, Part 2
posts.text: The outfits, accessories, and weaponry of our wonderful superheroine.

posts.title: Reader's Den: The Secret History of Wonder Woman, Part 1
posts.text: Welcome to the March 2015 Reader's Den! This month we'll be reading The Secret History of Wonder Woman by feminist historian Jill Lepore. Lepore details the life story of Wonder Woman's creator, William Moulton Marston.

posts.title: While You Wait to See Mockingjay... More Dystopian Fiction!
posts.text: Suzanne Collins's book Mockingjay has been split into two films. Here's a list of fiction titles to tide you over until Part Two comes out in November, or until you get a chance to see Part One.

posts.title: NYC Literary Haunts
posts.text: Bars, hotels, library branches, and other, more unexpected haunts.

posts.title: Haunted Real Estate and Furniture in Fiction
posts.text: The houses are full of horrors in these selected titles.

posts.title: Jock Reads and Flicks
posts.text: Just as the music CD Jock Jams inspired a generation to "Move It, Move It," many books and movies that focus on sports can be motivational, even if the reader or viewer is not interested in that particular activity.

posts.title: Muppets Run Amok at the Library
posts.text: In honor of the Sesame Street exhibition at the Library for the Performing Arts, I thought I'd write a bit about some other Jim Henson productions that have stayed with me.

posts.title: June 2014 Reader's Den: "The Judgment of Paris" Part 4
posts.text: In “In Praise of Art Forgeries” Blake Gopnik argues that muddying the ability to authenticate art works, as Warhol’s Factory artists did (sometimes attributed to him, sometimes not) can help to bring positive attention to works themselves, rather than their purely monetary value. As many letters to the editor in response suggested, this article may well have been mostly tongue-in-cheek. I suspect that he is questioning the role of the authenticator. This questioning of the role of art authentication is in some ways similar to the artists' questioning of the role of the Academy in "The

posts.title: June 2014 Reader's Den: "The Judgment of Paris" by Ross King, Part 3
June 2014 Reader's Den: "The Judgment of Paris" by Ross King, Part 2, About the Author
posts.text: About the Author: The critically acclaimed author of Brunelleschi's Dome, Leonardo and the Last Supper, and Machiavelli: Philosopher of Power, King is a native of Canada who has lived in England since 1992, currently outside Oxford.

posts.title: June 2014 Reader's Den: "The Judgment of Paris" by Ross King, Part 1
posts.text: Welcome back to the Reader's Den! This month we'll be looking at The Judgment of Paris by Ross King, about a turbulent era in art history.

posts.title: Epistolary Novels and Letter Writing
posts.text: "Epistolary" is one of those words that just fun to say or think about, like the word "condensation". An epistolary novel is simply a novel consisting of correspondence between characters. This is one of those rarely used writing devices, I assume because it's difficult to sustain throughout a novel.

posts.title: Meet the Speakers at our Fulton Fish Market Talk!
posts.text: This Wednesday, February 26 from 6-7:45 p.m. at Jefferson Market Library, come to an evening of memory, protest and plans. Here's some information about the upcoming speakers.

posts.title: Halloween Reads IV: The Repass
posts.text: It's that time of year again, when Halloween book and media picks are falling like harvest leaves. Here's a small, but spooky, selection.

Mermaid Parade

Flappers and Philosophers: F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald and Their Contemporaries
posts.text: A few titles that give a more substantial background to the time period in which "Gatsby" is set and to biographical details of F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald's lives.
